questions.question: A junior radiologist performing a fetal doppler follows the direction of the flow of oxygenatedblood from the placenta to the fetus to examine the fetal circulatory vessels. The sequencethat he would follow is:

options.A: Umbilical artery inferior vena cava → ductus venosus → right atrium → left atrium
options.B: Umbilical artery → superior vena cava → right atrium → ductus arteriosus → left atrium
options.C: Umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium
options.D: Umbilical vein → ductus arteriosus → superior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium

questions.question: Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by
questions.explanation: Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by the umbilical vein.The umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus into the inferior vena cava. Thus, theinferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lowerextremities carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage ofoxygen in the fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava.The umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta for oxygenation.Note:In the umbilical cord, there are a pair of umbilical arteries and a single umbilical vein.Mnemonic: AVA- artery -vein- artery(2 arteries and a single vein).

questions.question: A final year student is asked to give a seminar on 'fetal circulation.' Which among thefollowing statement told by him in the seminar is likely to be false?

options.A: Heart receives blood with high oxygen saturation
options.B: Pressure in right and left ventricles are equal
options.C: Liver receives blood with low oxygen saturation compared to the brain
options.D: Blood in inferior venacava has lower oxygen concentration compared to superior venacava

questions.explanation: Blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior venacava.451The superior vena cava carries the deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to theright atrium. The highly oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus from the placenta viathe umbilical vein with 50% of the umbilical venous blood entering the hepatic circulation and therest bypassing the liver and joining the inferior vena cava (IVC) via the ductus venosus. Hence, theblood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior venacava. Also, relatively a larger percentage of oxygen-rich blood is perfused to the brain.Pressures in both the right and left ventricles are equal in a developing fetus. The upper part ofthe body is perfused exclusively by the left ventricle while the lower extremities are perfused bythe right ventricle.

questions.question: The total fetal cardiac output at term is estimated to be
questions.explanation: The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.Approximately 65% of descending aortic blood flow returns to the placenta, and hence, only theremaining 35% perfuses the fetal organs and tissues.The clinical relevance of this 65% blood flow being directed to the placenta comes in the contextof delayed cord clamping vs early cord clamping after delivery. Delayed cord clamping entails theumbilical cord is clamped more than one minute after the birth or when cord pulsation hasceased. This delayed clamping allows the blood flow between the placenta and neonate tocontinue and helps improve the iron status in the infant.

questions.question: During the evaluation of a newborn, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. Where wouldthe structure responsible for the murmur ideally be located?

options.A: Just proximal to the left common carotid
options.B: Just distal to the left subclavian
options.C: Just distal to the left common carotid
options.D: Just proximal to the left subclavian

questions.explanation: Continuous machinery murmur in a newborn is characteristic of Patent ductus arteriosus. Mostcommonly, the ductus arteriosus is just distal to the left subclavian artery and the ductus entersthe pulmonary artery at its bifurcation.The image attached below shows the relations of ductus arteriosus.Ductus arteriosus relations Fetal circulation-RightbrachiocephalictrunkOMARROWLeft commoncarotid arteryLeft subclavianarteryLeftbrachiocephalictrunkPatent ductusarteriosusPulmonary artery452

questions.question: You assist the delivery of a 3.1 kg healthy term neonate by spontaneous vaginal delivery. Asthe baby transitions from the fetal circulation, what is the sequence of functional closure ofthe following structures?

options.A: Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus arteriosus
options.B: Ductus arteriosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus venosus
options.C: Ductus venosus --> Ductus arteriosus --> Foramen ovale
options.D: Ductus arteriosus --> Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale

questions.explanation: Functional closure of the fetal circulatory adjustments occurs in the following sequence: Ductusvenosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus arteriosusFetal circulatory adjustmentFunctional closureAnatomical closureDuctus venosusForamen ovaleAfter removal of the placentafrom fetal circulatory unitAt birth - after breathing is initiated7 daysMonths to yearsDuctus arteriosus10-15 hours10-21 days

questions.question: During the examination of a neonate with documented hearing defects and bilateral zonularcataracts, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. The mother gives a history of viralexanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. By when should the underlyingdefective channel that is responsible for the murmur anatomically close?
questions.explanation: The given vignette is suggestive of Patent ductus arteriosus in a child with congenital rubellasyndrome. The anatomical closure of the ductus arteriosus occurs at 10-21 days.Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated withrubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). PDA presents with a continuous machinerymurmur.Triad of congenital rubella syndrome• Sensorineural deafness• Congenital heart defects - MC is PDA• CataractsClassical rubella syndrome consists of:•• Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepperchorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis•• Ear defects: Sensorineural hearing loss due to destruction of organ of Corti• Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects453Changes in fetal circulation after birthLungs become the source of oxygenPulmonary vascular resistance decreasesand blood flow to lungs increasesSystemic vascular resistance and aortic pressureincreases due to increased venous returnfrom the lungsBlood flow through the ductus reversesHighly oxygenated blood flows from the aortathrough the ductus which creates a stimulus for themuscular spasm and subsequent closureOMARROWFetal circulatory adjustmentDuctus venosusFunctional closureAfter removal of the placentafrom fetal circulatory unitAnatomical closure7 daysForamen ovale-At birth after breathing is initiatedMonths to yearsDuctus arteriosus10-15 hours10-21 days

questions.question: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?

options.A: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

questions.explanation: Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure.Changes in fetal circulation after birthLungs become the source of oxygenPulmonary vascular resistance decreasesand blood flow to lungs increasesSystemic vascular resistance and aortic pressureincreases due to increased venous returnfrom the lungsBlood flow through the ductus reversesHighly oxygenated blood flows from the aortathrough the ductus which creates a stimulus for themuscular spasm and subsequent closureOMARROW454Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is lessresponsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus(PDA) is more common in premature infants.The fetal circulatory adjustments after birth are given below:The patency of ductus arteriosus may either provide an alternative route for blood to bypasscongenital defects such as pulmonary atresia or coarctation of the aorta.Therapeutic medications can be used to either maintain the patency (prostaglandin E1) orpromote closure (indomethacin). Drugs like indomethacin are not recommended during the thirdtrimester of pregnancy.Functional closureAnatomical closureDuctus venosusAfter removal of the placenta7 daysForamen ovale-At birth after breathing is initiatedMonths to yearsDuctus arterios10-15 hours10-21 daysus

questions.question: A newborn infant develops respiratory distress 2 days after birth. On examination, she ismottled and has weak upper extremity pulses and absent femoral pulses. Investigationsreveal the coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following drugs can you use to keep theductus open medically before surgical repair?
questions.explanation: Alprostadil, a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue, can be used to keep the ductus open medically inthe coarctation of the aorta.The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descendingaorta) is functionally closed at 10-15hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days afterbirth.Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic leftheart syndrome and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus.Closure of PDA in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia and cyanosis.PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle. PGE1 analogues like alprostadil,misoprost and rioprostil can be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply.In patent ductus arteriosus, the ductus is closed medically by NSAIDS (which inhibitprostaglandin synthesis) like ibuprofen trometamol/ ibuprofen lysine and indomethacin.Morphine can be used to manage respiratory distress but rarely preferred in a neonate.

questions.question: A 23-year-old woman with G2P1 and an Rh-negative pregnancy gave birth to a baby with anRh-positive blood group. The direct Coomb's test is positive. Cord blood bilirubin level ismore than 4 mg/dL. The team plans for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set upexchange transfusion. But the preferred vessel seems obliterated. This obliterated fibroticvessel would now be called as?
questions.explanation: The umbilical vein is the preferred vessel for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set upexchange transfusion. The obliterated remnant of the umbilical vein is the Ligamentum teres.The vessels that are occluded soon after birth are in due course replaced by fibrous tissue andforms the following ligaments:455The median umbilical ligament or Xander's ligament represents the remnant of the embryonicurachus.The lateral umbilical ligaments are folds of the peritoneum over the inferior epigastric arteries.Note:Cord blood bilirubin level more than 4 mg/dL is an indication for change transfusion in a neonate.Adult structureFetal structureForamen ovaleFossa ovalisUmbilical veinDuctus venosusUmbilical arterieSDuctus arteriosuSLigamentum teresLigamentum venosumMedial umbilical ligamentSLigamentum arteriosum456
